title: 114_hr1270
content: The "Restoring Access to Medication and Improving Health Savings Act of 2016" repeals disqualification of expenses for over-the-counter drugs under certain accounts and arrangements, effective after December 31, 2016. The "Health Care Security Act of 2016" allows both spouses to make catch-up contributions to the same health savings account. The amendment allows married individuals with family coverage under a high deductible health plan to combine their coverage for the purpose of contribution limits. The amendment allows married individuals with family coverage under a high deductible health plan to combine their coverage for contribution limits. The limitation on contributions is reduced by the amount paid to Archer MSAs of the spouses for the taxable year and divided equally between them unless agreed otherwise. If both spouses are over 55, the limitation subject to division includes additional contribution amounts. The amendment allows married individuals with family coverage under a high deductible health plan to combine their coverage for contribution limits. Additional contribution amounts determined under paragraph (3) for both spouses will be included in the limitation subject to division if both spouses are over 55. The amendment will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016. SEC. 203. Special rule for certain medical expenses incurred before establishment of health savings account. Section 223(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the treatment of certain medical expenses incurred before the establishment of a health savings account. This amendment applies to coverage beginning after December 31, 2016. SEC. 204: Contribution limit to Health Savings Account increased to deductible and out-of-pocket limitation. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the contribution limits for Health Savings Accounts for self-only and family coverage. Conforming amendments are also made, and the effective date for these changes is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2016. The "Protecting Taxpayers by Recovering Improper Obamacare Subsidy Overpayments Act" allows for the recovery of improper overpayments from federally subsidized health insurance. The amendment to Section 36B(f)(2)(B)(i) of the Internal Revenue Code limits the increase in subsidies for taxpayers with household income below 300 percent of the poverty line. The amendment sets dollar amounts for subsidies based on household income levels, ranging from $600 to $3,000. It applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2016.
